Here in Washington county Maine,  north coastal area, we are seeing much more heightened interactions between domestic dogs and coyotes, and even though the State says we do not have wolves, we in fact do. Coyotes are living and hunting in packs,  and the females will actually call domestic dogs to them when they are in heat. However, it often doesn't end well for the dog,  who is killed by the pack. I nearby Newfoundland,  they have also found coyotes that had definitely interbred with wolves, and this pack actively hunted humans,  among other critters. They killed a solitary female hiker. So interbreeding by these three types of canids is real, and increasing and definitely changing the wild canids

Cougars have made their move but we must support it, and I am hoping wolves follow. The lack of large predators in the American prairies is devastating. Coyotes overpopulate and are not fun to have around. Badgers also tend to do better and destroy farmland. Though, knowing deer starve to death because of harsh winters and overpopulation is the worst. My family has welcomed the string of cougar sighting near our farm, but it's still not a breeding population. Yes, we are now definitely carrying a firearm when the sun is set if we are walking far but only as a last resort...whereas coyotes, feral hogs, certain varmint, we are likely to shoot on sight and have done so for generations

Idk if it's actually normal but I could swear that I've seen the Magpies in my region of Finland split into two distinct species, I'm saying this because nowhere else in Finland are there clearly two types of magpies:
- A-Kind: Rough feathers, less white, smaller than crows but bigger than jackdaws
- B-Kind: Smooth feathers, more white, smaller than jackdaws, some have yellow rings around their eyes
They hang out in distinct flocks, like if there was both kinds in a big group, if someone walked past the A-Kind would all simultaneously fly away but the B-Kind would stay pecking at the ground, the A-Kind might chase the B-Kind away or vice-versa in similiar ways to how crows treat magpies in their territory, etc that kind of behaviour
Plus the A-Kind sit on rooftops a lot but the B-Kind look for food on the ground and sit in trees for some reason

So the existence of Coywolfs that are not sterile hybrids basically means that Coyotes and Wolves are not separate species but in fact Sub-Species (not closely related species (difference)) of each other as a speciation event states that either they are unable to successfully produce offspring with similar species or produce fertile offspring i.e like the Horse and Donkey creating a first generation infertile offspring = Mule. Their differing Phenotype can confuse the fact they have similar genotypes to allow fertile (successful) interbreeding.
This is also the case with the American Ruddy Duck (invasive species) and mediterranean/Asian White-headed Duck (endangered) that were thought to be previously separate species.
Isn't this an example of adaptation (ecology) than evolution? as the suggestion that they could be classified as their own species as they become more genetically distinct overtime is a bit woolly as such events are supposed to take millions of years, When the speciation event occurs - this is would of course be more pronounce if the Coywolf itself was in genetic isolation as the continual interbreeding merely reinforces genetic compatibility and therefore non-speciation.
They could be classified as a separate subspecies if they are distinct enough so they are more taxonomy Canis (genus). Latrans (Coyote - species) Lupi (wolf - subspecies) as opposed to a Canis Castellum (or something like that).
I Continue to enjoy watching Scishow and the myriad of interesting facts and myth busting :). Keep up the dissemination of knowledge.
Maybe an episode on what speciation is to help clarify points. and possibly on the factors like Phenotypes and Genotypes which this episodes eludes to with many species previously at first glance looking like (i.e. phenotype) another species but in fact being genetically different (genotype) and it is the genotype that we base species classification.

Had a coywolf as a pet when I was younger.

There was a crazy coot that lived close by, and had a tendency to force breed these kind of things. He had many dangerous animals in pens, and was a bit unstable.

One of the pups escaped we think, and we found her injured. She was timid but curious.

We took her home and cleaned and fed her, healed her up. Turned out she had a massive thorn in her face causing a persistent wound. She became part of the family quickly.

She was the smartest dog/thing we ever had. Could open doors, and was very adherent to pack structure, making her extremely obedient. She was also very friendly to everyone, neighbors and the like.

She still retained much of her wild nature, and would hunt her own food most of the time. We lived in the county, surrounded by forested areas.

She even tried to hunt/provide for the family, and on a hike, she dropped a squirrel in front of my mother. Not a mark on it, she crushed it's ribs but did not leave any teeth marks. Freaked my mother out, and when my mother threw it away, it made the dog sad. She never hunted for the family again. My mother felt bad and had wished she had the foresight to dispose of the squirrel out of sight of the dog.

She was a great dog, and she lived to be 17yo, I think the move into town when she was around 14 was worse on her than actual age. As she had to be confined to a fenced yard.

It makes sense to me that new species would arise in places like city parks--they are small, relatively isolated populations. Just like islands, unique species tend to emerge.

On another note, Eastern Coyotes aren't just in cities, they are ubiquitous throughout the Northeast. Our forested rural areas are pretty much completely staked out into various coyote pack territories. We hear them at night all the time. They are beautiful animals.

We know that we're missing millions of species because almost every species that is not itself a parasite has at least one species of parasite exclusive to it (also many parasites do as well).

Just think, every time there a species whose extinction makes the headline there's probably some flatworm, or parasitic protozoan or liver fluke or some other form of parasite whose tiny voice is silenced forever. :-(

If we're being technical, the reason microsatellites differ isn't that they inherently mutate more, it's moreso that since they don't code for proteins, a mutation is less likely to be deleterious. Since a mutation in the satellites isn't selected against, they tend to accumulate more quickly, but the actual occurrence of mutations isn't any higher in micro satellites.

Middle of October I was on my back porch in Worcester Massachusetts, getting ready to take some pictures of the foliage when a dog appeared. As I looked at him undetected, it looked like a wolf but smaller, or possibly a coyote. I took a few pictures, then it ran in front of my garage, over a small fence and back behind the garage. It re-appeared then headed back into the woods, Now I noticed it was not alone, it was working with another to get a meal. I checked the internet and found that it is most likely coywolf.
